localization.primary_language: English (reference text), plus all 24 official EU languages
document_languages: English (universal — all templates must be available in EN)
German (largest EU economy, strong AI ecosystem)
French (co-official EU language, France has significant AI activity)

terminology.definition: A machine-based system designed to operate with varying levels of autonomy that infers from input how to generate outputs (Art. 3(1))
terminology.usage_context: Core term used throughout all UI screens, documents, and compliance workflows

terminology.definition: Entity that develops an AI system or GPAI model and places it on market under its own name (Art. 3(3))
terminology.usage_context: Role selector in onboarding, obligation filtering, dashboard labels

terminology.definition: Entity using an AI system under its authority, except for personal non-professional use (Art. 3(4))
terminology.usage_context: Role selector in onboarding, obligation filtering, dashboard labels

local_terms.es: sistema de IA de alto riesgo
local_terms.it: sistema di IA ad alto rischio
local_terms.pt: sistema de IA de alto risco

terminology.definition: AI system falling under Article 6 criteria (Annex II product safety or Annex III use cases)
terminology.usage_context: Risk classification results, obligation cards, compliance score breakdown

terminology.definition: Process of verifying that a high-risk AI system meets all AI Act requirements (Art. 43)
terminology.usage_context: Provider compliance workflow, assessment status tracking

local_terms.fr: analyse d'impact sur les droits fondamentaux
local_terms.es: evaluación de impacto en derechos fundamentales
local_terms.pt: avaliação de impacto nos direitos fundamentais

terminology.definition: Assessment public/certain private deployers must conduct before deploying high-risk AI (Art. 27)
terminology.usage_context: FRIA workflow, deployer compliance dashboard, document templates

local_terms.es: modelo de IA de uso general
local_terms.it: modello di IA per finalità generali
local_terms.pt: modelo de IA de finalidade geral

terminology.definition: AI model displaying significant generality, capable of performing wide range of distinct tasks (Art. 3(63))
terminology.usage_context: Classification workflow, GPAI provider obligations section

terminology.definition: Skills, knowledge and understanding allowing informed deployment and use of AI systems (Art. 3(56))
terminology.usage_context: Training module, AI literacy obligation card, compliance checklist

localization.date_format: DD/MM/YYYY (EU standard) or YYYY-MM-DD (ISO 8601 for technical/API use)
localization.currency: EUR (€) — all fines and financial references in euros
cultural_notes: EU is not a monolithic market — compliance culture, enforcement intensity, and AI adoption vary significantly across Member States
Germany has the strongest compliance culture and is likely to be among the first/strictest enforcers. Prioritize DE localization.
France has a strong AI industry (Mistral, etc.) and active regulatory engagement. FR localization is high priority.
Netherlands is a major tech hub with relatively pragmatic regulatory approach.
Nordic countries (SE, DK, FI) have high AI adoption and value transparency — green/sustainability positioning resonates.
Southern/Eastern EU markets may have longer adoption curves but are catching up rapidly.
Works councils (Betriebsräte in Germany) are a major factor in worker notification obligations — strong cultural and legal importance.
Data protection culture is deeply ingrained in EU — GDPR compliance is baseline expectation. AI Act compliance should be positioned as GDPR's natural extension.
Many EU companies already have ISO 27001 or similar certifications — position AI Act compliance as complementary to existing frameworks.

version.source_regulation_version: Regulation (EU) 2024/1689 as published in OJ L 2024/1689
version.last_regulatory_update_checked: 2025-12-17 (Code of Practice on content marking draft)
version.notes: Production-grade framework with granular obligation decomposition, full what_not_to_do coverage, expanded deployer obligations, and comprehensive tech specs for scanner.
